subject: RE: [junit] Naming Conventions
msgSnippet: Matt, After reading your email I went back and refactored one of my test classes to use descriptions instead of numbers. The names were not so awkward after
messageBody:
Matt,

After reading your email I went back and refactored one of my test
classes to use descriptions instead of numbers.

The names were not so awkward after all.

I think you are correct. Using a brief description in the names of
test methods is better than using a numbering system.

test_nameOfMethodBeingTested_description

Thanks.

Mike


--- "Di Iorio, Matthew (ISS Atlanta)" <mdiiorio@...> wrote:
> >We did consider using descriptive names for the test methods, for
> >example
> >
> > test_isPartnerAssigned_nullArgument
> >
> >However, this got to be real awkward real fast. So instead we
> choose
>
> Why is that awkward? It's very convenient for me to be able to
> look at the
> name of the test that failed is see immediately what is being
> tested. And I
> only have to type it once.
>
> >The basic question is, "When you have multiple test methods that
> test
> >a single method, what naming convention do you use for the test
> >methods?"
>
> We concentrate more on testing behavior of a class rather than
> testing each
> method explicitly. Below are methods from one of our tests. These
> all are
> testing the create() method on a factory class. Notice how we
> aren't really
> concerned about the method name, but more about behavior.
>
> public void testBuiltIns() throws Exception {
> public void testDupsAreBad() throws Exception {
> public void testNoSimpleType() throws Exception {
> public void testUnsupportedSimpleTypeNoDefault() throws Exception
> {
> public void testUnsupportedSimpleTypeDefaultString() throws
> Exception {
> public void testUnsupportedSimpleTypeDefaultStringBaseUnknown()
> throws Exception {
> public void testUnsupportedSimpleTypeNoDefaultList() throws
> Exception {
>
> Matt
